DataElement.preferredName: Disease Progression And/Or Conversion Difference Myelodysplastic Syndrome And/Or Myeloproliferative Neoplasm Subtype Indicator
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The indicator that describes whether or not if there was a disease progression and/or transformation to a different myelodysplastic/myeloproliferative neoplasm subtype.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Disease Progression And/Or Conversion Difference Myelodysplastic Syndrome And/Or Myeloproliferative Neoplasm Subtype
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The worsening of a disease over time_Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options may be valid._The act of changing the nature, form, function, or purpose of something to another._The quality of being unlike or dissimilar._A clonal hematopoietic disorder characterized by dysplasia and ineffective hematopoiesis in one or more of the hematopoietic cell lines.  The dysplasia may be accompanied by an increase in myeloblasts, but the number is less than 20%, which, according to the WHO guidelines, is the requisite threshold for the diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia.  It may occur de novo or as a result of exposure to alkylating agents and/or radiotherapy.  (WHO, 2001)_Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options may be valid._A clonal hematopoietic stem cell disorder, characterized by proliferation in the bone marrow of one or more of the myeloid (i.e., granulocytic, erythroid, megakaryocytic, and mast cell) lineages. It is primarily a neoplasm of adults. (WHO 2008)_A group forming a type within a larger type.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The worsening of a disease over time:Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options may be valid.:The act of changing the nature, form, function, or purpose of something to another.:The quality of being unlike or dissimilar.

Concepts.definition: A process that manifests as the worsening of a disease over time.
Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options may be valid.
The act of changing the nature, form, function, or purpose of something to another.
The quality of being unlike or dissimilar.

Property.preferredName: Myelodysplastic Syndrome And/Or Myeloproliferative Neoplasm Subtype
Property.preferredDefinition: A clonal hematopoietic disorder characterized by dysplasia and ineffective hematopoiesis in one or more of the hematopoietic cell lines. The dysplasia may be accompanied by an increase in myeloblasts, but the number is less than 20%, which, according to the WHO guidelines, is the requisite threshold for the diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia. It may occur de novo or as a result of exposure to alkylating agents and/or radiotherapy. (WHO, 2001):Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options may be valid.:A clonal hematopoietic stem cell disorder, characterized by proliferation in the bone marrow of one or more of the myeloid (i.e., granulocytic, erythroid, megakaryocytic, and mast cell) lineages. It is primarily a neoplasm of adults. (WHO 2008):A group forming a type within a larger type.

Concepts.definition: A clonal hematopoietic disorder characterized by dysplasia and ineffective hematopoiesis in one or more of the hematopoietic cell lines. The dysplasia may be accompanied by an increase in myeloblasts, but the number is less than 20%, which, according to the WHO guidelines, is the requisite threshold for the diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia. It may occur de novo or as a result of exposure to alkylating agents and/or radiotherapy. (WHO, 2001)
Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options may be valid.

A group of myeloid neoplasms that includes the following: chronic myeloid leukemia, BCR-ABL1 positive; polycythemia vera; essential thrombocythemia;  primary myelofibrosis; chronic neutrophilic leukemia; chronic eosinophilic leukemia, not otherwise specified; and myeloproliferative neoplasm, unclassifiable.
A group forming a type within a larger type.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).
